citation.article-title: Achromobacter gen. nov. and Achromobacter xylosoxidans (ex Yabuuchi and Ohyama 1971) nom. rev.

p.s: Description of Achromobacter xylosoxidans sp. nov., nom. rev.
Achromobacter xylosoxidans (ex Yabuuchi and Ohyama 1971) nom. rev. (xylos ox'idans. M.L. xylos xylose; M.L.v. oxido make acid, oxidize; M.L. part.adj. xylosoxidans oxidizing xylose).
Gram-negative, nonsporeforming, straight rods 0.8 to 1.2 by 2.5 to 3.0 μm, with rounded ends.
Motile and peritrichous.
The number of flagella is one to nine per cell.
Strictly aerobic and nonfermentative.
Definite acidity is produced promptly at the top of OF xylose medium without a paraffin seal.
Oxidative acid production from glucose, galactose, mannose, and D-arabinose is usually slow and weak.
Indophenol oxidase and catalase positive; urease, gelatinase and deoxyribonuclease negative; 3- ketolactose is not produced from lactose.
The guanine-pluscytosine content of the deoxyribonucleic acid is in the range of 65 to 70 mol%.

A detailed study and description of 75 phenotypic characters of 55 strains, the guanine-plus-cytosine contents of the deoxyribonucleic acids of 20 strains of this species, and a set of characters useful in the identification of A. xylosoxiduns have been published previously.
The major fatty acid components of cell-bound lipids are 2-hydroxydodecanoic acid (25.6 to 33.6%), 2-hydroxytetradecanoic acid (16.4 to 22.4%), and 3-hydroxytetradecanoic acid (31.1 to 37.6%).

A. xylosoxiduns has been isolated from various kinds of pathological specimens, including blood, spinal fluid, pleural fluid, peritoneal fluid, pus, urine, stools, and swabs of eyes, ears, and pharynxes.
Although its natural habitat is not known, this organism is frequently found in unsterilized “distilled” water and in chlorhexidine solutions in hospitals.
The type strain is ATCC 27061.
The description of the type strain is identical to that of the species.
